text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Burberry spice that's right
i've wanted to show you this amazing
ethiopian spice blend for so long but
I've just never gotten around to it and
I think one of the reasons is that I'm
always afraid these kind of demos aren't
going to be excited enough because it's
basically three minutes of watching me
put different colored powders into a
bowl but then I remember that's not a
very good excuse
since a lot of the footage in these
videos isn't exciting so I decided to go
for it and to make up for the boring
first part of the video once we make our
burberry I'm going to show you one of my
favorite uses for it so that should hold
you but anyway let's go ahead and get
started with the aforementioned adding
stuff to a bowl and I'm going to be
starting with some dry ground New Mexico
chili and you might be thinking New
Mexico chili that doesn't sound very
Ethiopian well it's not but it works for
this which reminds me I will be going
into a little more detail about your
chili choices on the blog post and then
to that we're going to add some paprika
just regular not smoked just sweet
paprika which brings us to our third and
last chili powder ground cayenne I know
you didn't see that coming so that's
going to be it for our chili powder base
and right here I saw what I thought
could be some hard lumps and I was
thinking about sifting this but as I
examined with my freakishly small wooden
spoon it turned out to be nothing so
let's go ahead and continue on with the
rest of the ingredients which will
include some onion powder some garlic
powder some ground ginger some ground
cumin you know what I want to stop
saying ground everything's going to be
ground here but anyway continue it out
we also want some coriander as well as
some cardamom as well as the always
exotic fenugreek oh you heard me
fenugreek and then we're definitely
going to also need to add some cinnamon
as well as some nutmeg and know that was
not ground that was of course freshly
grated and then we will finish up with
some allspice as well as some clove and
that is going to be it all we have left
to do is take a whisk and give this a
very very thorough mixing and by the way
if you are wondering about salt a lot of
people do like to add some at this point
but I don't I want to be able to control
the salt content depending on what kind
of recipe I'm going to use this for so I
don't add any in but of course that's
going to be up to you you're the boss to
making sure your Berber a
is BAE and while we're on the subject
it's my understanding there's like five
or six million different versions of
this so there really is no standard set
of ingredients not that that's going to
prevent people from assisting there are
but the point is is hopefully you're
just going to use this as a template and
really adjust this to your own tastes
and then what we'll do once that's all
mixed together is transferred into some
kind of airtight container where we
could then store that up to a long time
I'm not sure and usually at this point
we would taste for seasoning but that
brings us to the age-old dilemma how do
you taste a seasoning for seasoning it's
the same thing as how do you watch dirty
soap so what we're going to have to do
is use it for food and then adjust if
need be and so with that let me go ahead
and show you one of my favorite uses for
this Berber a spice and that would be
believe it or not for a boneless
skinless chicken breast and like we just
went over since there's no salt in the
blend we'll go ahead and start by
seasoning this generously with some
kosher salt before sprinkling over
whatever we consider is an adequate
amount of spice again something that's
up to you but as you can see I'm going
to be fairly generous and by the way if
you're not into the boneless skinless
chicken breast and really why would you
be this could just as easily be a piece
of pork or a piece of lamb or or who
knows maybe even some tofu or a
cauliflower steak oh yes they're calling
thick pieces of cauliflower steaks now
which I guess is legal but anyway we're
going to apply our salt and spice blend
to both sides at which point you could
place that in the fridge and let it
absorb those flavors for an hour or two
but if you want and I do you can cook
this immediately so I'm going to head to
the stove where I placed a skillet over
medium-high heat where I toasted a
little bit of butter until it just
started to turn golden brown and we're
going to place our chicken breast in and
cook that for a couple minutes per side
and ideally we're not going to cook this
chicken breast all the way through okay
we want to go about maybe 75% of the way
because what we're going to do once
we've seared this on both sides for a
couple minutes is remove that from the
skillet and then we'll make a quick
little pan sauce and then finish our
chicken in that so like I said we're
going to give that a couple minutes per
side and in addition to giving that
chicken breast some beautiful color is
our Berber a spice kind of toast to the
surface of that chicken as it cooks
that's what's going to release all those
amazing flavors and aromas it is quite a
sight to behold and more importantly
smell
but anyway once we've given that a
couple minutes per side we'll go ahead
and remove that from the pan and quickly
deglaze with the juice of a lime as well
as a little touch of tomato paste for a
little extra acidity and color and
basically what I'm trying to accomplish
here is a very quick very easy coconut
milk-based curry sauce for the lack of a
better term so I'm going to finish up
with a splash of chicken broth as well
as some coconut milk and not the low fat
one the real one with all the fat and
we'll go ahead and we'll stir all that
together and wait for that to come up to
a simmer and start to reduce and then
sometimes depending on my mood I'll
actually toss in a little extra pinch of
our burberry spice and that's going to
hopefully give it a little extra certain
something plus that bit of spice didn't
get toasted so we're going to get a
little bit of a different flavor and
then because my chicken broth wasn't
salted I'm going to add a little pinch
here and like I said we're going to let
that come to a simmer and sort of reduce
down just a little bit at which point we
will add our chicken breast back in and
we'll lower our heat down to medium-low
and all we're going to do is continue on
basting that chicken for a couple
minutes until it's cooked through and
our sauce is thickened up to our liking
and I should have mentioned I did
problem that chicken breast out a little
bit so it has sort of a uniform
thickness which is always going to make
things easier so this is going to cook
more evenly but anyway like I said we'll
continue on on medium low until our
chicken is cooked through and we're
happy with our sauce at which point
we'll turn off the heat and finish this
by adding some freshly chopped cilantro
and we'll mix that in and other than
giving it one last taste for salt and
seasoning we are done and ready to plate
up and I'm not sure exactly what kind of
pan sauces you've been looking at but
for me this is one of the most beautiful
ones you'll ever see I mean look at that
color that is so gorgeous who cares what
this even tastes like of course having
said that this tastes just as good as it
looks so I'm going to serve that up next
to some prop asparagus check it out it
looks so lifelike
but anyway forget the asparagus let me
go ahead and grab a fork and knife and
tear into this chicken and I'm not
really sure why I'm using a knife
because cooked as shown the chicken
breast should be tender enough to eat
with a fork which I will prove
throughout the rest of the video but
anyway I took a bite
and it really was amazing and also
frustrating because I find it almost
impossible to describe things like this
it's kind of spicy and sweet and bitter
and tangy and aromatic and fragrant and
complex whatever that means there's
almost too much going on to describe but
if in general you enjoy the spice
profiles of curries I really think
you're going to like this a lot and not
only is this easy interesting and fairly
exotic it's also incredibly versatile
pretty much any recipe that calls for
chili powder or paprika or cajun
seasoning or curry powder you can make
with this instead and I think it's going
to be just as delicious if not more so
okay so I really do hope you give this a
try soon head over to food wishes comm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
you
[Music]
